pages:
Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46021-001  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Credit and Social Rating 
System Development for Microcredit Companies  
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 22 November 2012) 
 
Currency unit  –  yuan (CNY) 
CNY1.00  =  $0.1602 
$1.00  =  CNY6.244 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
MCC  –  microcredit company 
PBC  –  People’s Bank of China 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention—MDGs 
Sector (subsector)  –  Finance (finance sector development, microfinance) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (widening access to markets and economic 
opportunities), governance (economic and financial governance) 
Location (impact)  –  Rural (high), national (medium)  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  S. Groff, Operations 2 
Director General  R. Wihtol, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  Y. Qian, Public Management, Financial Sector, and Regional 
Cooperation Division, EARD 
 
Team leader  S. Lee, Financial Sector Specialist, EARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2011  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a technical 
assistance (TA) for Credit and Social Rating System Development for Microcredit Companies 
(MCCs), starting with arrangements in Heilongjiang province.1 The April 2012 mission confirmed 
the  strong  commitment  of  the  PRC  and  Heilongjiang  governments,  and  reached  an 
understanding with the PRC government on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, cost estimates, 
financing plan, implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
2.  The ADB country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for the PRC includes inclusive growth 
as its first pillar, also a core value of the PRC’s 12th Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. Improving 
access to finance and management of natural resources are the two main areas of support. The 
TA directly supports inclusive growth by providing better information on microcredit company 
(MCC) operations and their financial and social impacts. Ratings will also help policy makers 
understand and improve rules to increase financial access. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The PRC’s outstanding economic performance3 is accompanied by a number of serious 
imbalances—between coastal and inland regions, between urban and rural areas, and between 
high  demand  for  natural  resources  and  the  need  for  energy  efficiency  and  environmental 
conservation. The government and ADB consider the development of inclusive finance to be a 
key  policy  measure to achieve  inclusive  growth.4 The  PRC  banking  system  has  played  a 
dominant role in the financial market by mobilizing a large pool of deposits and providing an 
estimated 95% of corporate financing. However, many small and medium-sized enterprises and 
poor households are confronted by serious difficulties in accessing credit.5   
 
4.  In  2004,  People’s  Bank  of  China  (PBC)  decided  to  open  the  financial  market  to 
microcredit operations. That same year, ADB provided TA to support establishment of private 
sector-sponsored microfinance institutions.6 The first seven MCCs began operation in late 2006; 
the market has continued to grow exponentially. The latest PBC statistics indicate that as of  
31 March 2012, 4,878 MCCs, with 53,501 employees, were operating in the country. They had 
a  total  loan  balance  of  CNY444.7  billion  and  total  paid-in  capital  of  CNY387.1  billion. 
Heilongjiang  province,  the  proponent  for  this  TA,  has  317  registered  MCCs  covering  all 
municipalities and 80% of counties. The companies serve 69,000 business clients and have 
total registered capital of CNY9.68 billion. They are regulated in a nonprudential manner by the 
Heilongjiang Provincial Office of Financial Affairs. 
 
                                                
1  The TA is included in ADB. 2012. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2012–2014. 
Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 13 December 2012.  
3  Real gross domestic product growth for 2011 was 9.2% and inflation 4.1%. Foreign direct investment reached an 
all-time high of $115.86 billion in 2011. 
4  An inclusive financial system is one that services all clients, not just the relatively well off. This means servicing 
poor and low-income clients with a wide range of accessible products. 
5  This is due to unreliable financial reporting, lack of collateral and guarantees, lack of credit-rating and general 
credit information, and loan officer responsibility for loan losses. 
6  ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Rural Finance Reforms and Development 
of Microfinance Institutions. Manila (TA 4430-PRC, for $1,000,000, approved on 9 November 2004).

2   
5.  Increasing  resources  to  MCCs  and  their  borrowers  will  encourage  private  sector 
participation  in  economic  growth,  creating  more  employment  opportunities  and  increased 
income.  Additionally,  access  to  microcredit  and  other  financial  services  helps  the  poor  to 
improve incomes and withstand economic shocks. ADB has continuously supported the rural 
and microfinance subsectors in the PRC. In addition to its groundbreaking work in 2004 to 
develop  privately  owned  commercially  sustainable  microfinance  institutions,  ADB  is  now 
partnering with (i) PBC to support innovations in rural and microfinance, and improve rural 
finance statistics; (ii) the China Banking Regulatory Commission to strengthen the rural finance 
regulatory framework; and (iii) local banks to channel funds to MCCs and the microfinance 
market through wholesale funding facilities. 
 
6.  The Heilongjiang provincial government views MCCs as significant for increasing of jobs 
and legalization of enterprises. Key issues for MCCs include sensitivity to rapid changes in 
market demand for funds, and higher taxation and more challenging policy environments than 
for  other  financial  institutions.  Other  TA  projects  and  ongoing  consultations  with  PBC  are 
addressing these issues. MCCs are limited by the size of their capital base and geographic 
coverage (only one county each) and are primarily financed by owners’ equity investments. 
Most MCCs deploy their entire capital base in 2–3 months and have to depend on recycling of 
funds. Loans to MCC clients are usually 3–6 months in duration and finance the working capital 
needs of their clients. MCC borrowing from commercial banks is severely limited, as banks are 
wary of the unrated financial firms, which are relatively young and not fully regulated. Investors 
are equally hesitant about placing equity into MCCs, as they are uncertain of the quality of 
operations, assets, and management. Independent ratings of MCCs would significantly improve  
equity investments and lending capacity.  
 
7.  While an initial credit-rating arrangement for MCCs is being considered and developed 
under a small grant from the Gender and Development Fund, no market-established system of 
rating firms is available to provide assessments of MCCs on financial and social performance. 
Private rating firms have not entered this market due to the relatively recent development of 
MCCs and uncertainty if firms will pay for the ratings. The lack of comparative information on 
MCCs has resulted in severe restrictions on lending and equity investments in many MCCs. 
Heilongjiang  provincial  government  has  proposed  this  arrangement  to  strengthen  its  MCC 
market. 
 
8.  The  development  of  competitive  ratings  for  the  MCC  market  is  important  for  three 
reasons.  First,  regulation  is  decentralized  to  the  provinces,  and  rating  systems  will  help 
regulators track the development and performance independent of their own oversight. Second, 
the MCC market is constrained by limitations on capital and restrictive borrowing, and ratings 
will  help  strengthen  MCCs  to  attract funds to  grow  and  engage  with  banks  as  wholesale 
financiers. Third, establishment of a system of financial and social performance ratings will help 
the PRC government determine the social impact of MCCs, and the national and provincial 
governments to develop policies to encourage and promote MCCs, which provide financial 
support to lower-income households and encourage rebalancing of resources. In this way, the 
PRC can build appropriate systems to support their financial and social benefits.

3 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be improved investment quality of MCCs in the PRC. The outcome will 
be a competitive market for social and financial performance ratings for MCCs in Heilongjiang 
province. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will help develop financial and social performance rating systems for MCCs in 
the PRC, starting with arrangements in Heilongjiang province. Three rating firms will be selected 
based on international and local rating experiences in microfinance markets. The three selected 
firms will develop dual financial and social credit ratings for MCCs, and work with provincial 
regulators to help them understand the rationale, systems, and use of the ratings. The rating 
fees for the initial set of MCCs will be covered by the TA, and banks and MCC investors will be 
provided with information on how ratings can be used for MCC engagement.  
 
11.  The TA will deliver three major outputs, with following activities:  
 
(i)  Three rating firms with social and financial rating systems for microcredit 
companies. The TA will (a) review international best practice in financial and 
social performance ratings for MCCs, (b) determine methodology for rating MCCs, 
and (c) develop selection criteria for candidate rating firms in close collaboration 
with EA/IA. Experienced and capable ratings agencies will join the TA to develop 
the social and financial rating system. 
(ii)  Fifteen microcredit companies with social and financial ratings. The TA will 
(a) identify and select candidate MCCs for the social and financial ratings based 
on  predetermined  criteria,  which  will  be  developed  in  more  detail  with  the 
government; (b) test the rating systems with candidate MCCs and revise and 
update the system based on the results; and (c) share overall process, results 
and implications with the provincial regulators. The final output will be 15 MCCs 
with social and financial ratings based on the established rating methodology and 
system well responsive to the potential demand in MCCs ratings in Heilongjiang 
Province. 
(iii)  Rating firms approved by provincial regulators in Heilongjiang province for 
rating  microcredit  companies.  The  TA  will  (a)  reflect  views  and 
recommendations  of  all  interested  stakeholders,  including  provincial  finance 
bureaus, PBC, the women’s federation, and others; (b) improve the existing data 
reporting formats for the rating system; and (c) develop criteria for the provincial 
regulator’s approval of rating firms for MCCs. The provincial financial market 
offices will determine rating firms acceptable for MCC ratings. 
 
12.  Heilongjiang Provincial Finance Department, the executing agency, and the Heilongjiang 
Provincial Office of Financial Affairs, the implementing agency, will select MCCs to be rated 
using the following criteria: the five largest MCCs by loan portfolio, the five MCCs with the 
lowest average loan size, and the next five oldest MCCs. In this way the market will be reviewed 
in terms of largest organizations that have market impact, those with the likely highest social 
agenda (as those providing smaller loans are targeting poorer clients), and MCCs with the 
longest operating history.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of data access, office space, logistics support, and other 
in-kind contributions. Appendix 2 provides the cost estimates and financing plan. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  Heilongjiang  Provincial  Finance  Department  will  be  the  executing  agency  (EA)  and 
Heilongjiang Provincial Office of Financial Affairs will be the implementing agency (IA). 
 
15.  The TA will commence on 1 February 2013 and close on 31 May 2015. It will finance  
(i)  three  lump  sum  contracts  for  consultants  to  support  rating  companies  (an  estimated 
equivalent  of  15  person-months  of  blended  international  and  national  consultant  time)  to 
develop and test rating systems; and (ii) training, workshops, and miscellaneous expenses. 
Three firms will be contracted to develop ratings under the consultants qualification selection 
method with a ceiling of $100,000 per firm, based on recent prior cost experience developing 
ratings for MCCs under the Gender and Development Fund. The rating companies will also 
provide training to regulators on the results; this cost is separate in the budget and will be paid 
from  the  TA  by  the  Heilongjiang  Provincial  Finance  Department  under  advance  payment 
facilities. ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference are provided in 
Appendix 3. 
 
16.  The TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010 as amended from time to time). An assessment of Heilongjiang 
Finance Bureau capacity will not be undertaken as the bureau has implemented previous ADB 
projects and its expenditure will be limited to paying for site costs of training activities under 
advance payment facilities. 
 
17.  ADB and the Heilongjiang Provincial Finance Department will review TA operations in 
the field three times a year. Market reporting of ratings in the public domain will demonstrate the 
results.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China for  Credit  and  Social  Rating  System 
Development for Microcredit Companies, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 2  7 
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN 
($’000)

Note: The technical assistance is estimated to cost $450,000, of which contributions from the Asian Development 
Bank are presented in the table. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of data access, office 
space, and logistics support, and other in-kind contributions. The value of government contribution is estimated to 
account for 11% of the total TA cost. 
a   Financed by the Asian Development Bank’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
b  Three rating firms with prior experience in designing and implementing financial and social ratings for microfinance 
organizations will be recruited on a competitive basis to develop and deliver ratings for microcredit companies 
(MCCs). The cost estimate is based on prior experience with the development of one MCC rating system through 
the Gender and Development Fund at a cost of $100,000. 
c  All training includes translation and interpretation costs, and cost of translating the report into English. Heilongjiang 
Finance Bureau will cover all costs in excess of those budgeted here.  
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

8  Appendix 3   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE  
1.  The technical assistance includes the development of microcredit company (MCC) 
rating systems. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage three rating firms that are 
internationally qualified and experienced in rating microfinance organizations under lump sum 
contracts of $100,000 each, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
2.  The rating firms are required to have significant ratings experience in microfinance 
markets and/or in financial markets in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), with an express 
intention to develop MCC ratings as a part of their business product lines. They will be 
required to disclose their methodology on a confidential basis to provincial MCC regulators. 
 
3.  Each rating firm will work closely with the Heilongjiang Finance Bureau (the executing 
agency) and selected microcredit companies to complete detailed tasks as follows (equivalent 
to 5 person-months for each rating firm, intermittent): 
 
(i)  Assess and discuss with MCCs and provincial regulators the firm’s experience and 
any  international  good  examples  of  financial  and  social  development  rating 
systems for microfinance organizations, and how these can be incorporated into 
rating systems in Heilongjiang province.  
(ii)  Review and summarize information available on MCC market development and 
trends, with attention to any financial and social performance data available. 
(iii)  Select five MCCs as partners to develop the rating systems. 
(iv)  Determine  methodology  for  rating  MCCs,  linking  this  to  any  overall  market 
assessments, surveys, or other review processes. 
(v)  Test the rating systems with the partner MCCs, revise, and finalize. 
(vi)  Share results with each MCC, and revise and discuss accordingly. 
(vii)  Share overall results and implications with provincial regulators and ADB.  
(viii)  Discuss rating system, uses, and options with provincial finance bureaus, banks, 
People’s  Bank  of  China,  the  women’s  federation,  and  other  interested 
stakeholders; and recommend changes to existing formats for MCC provincial 
reporting to allow for improved data for ratings. 
(ix)  Provide a final report, in English and Chinese, with rating results, options for 
market expansion and rating use, and a rating firm strategy for expansion in the 
PRC. 
 
4.  By 1 month after mobilization, each rating firm will submit an inception report providing 
a work plan with dates of anticipated milestones and outputs, along with a field plan and 
requirements for executing agency (Heilongjiang Finance Bureau) time and collaboration.  
Each firm will be required to provide deliverables consistent with the design and monitoring 
framework activities, outputs, and delivery dates: an MCC rating system for financial and 
social ratings; ratings for each of five MCCs; and completion of training and concurrence by 
the provincial MCC regulator that the ratings firm is qualified to undertake rating of MCCs in 
the province. Reports are to be of high quality  and produced in English, with copies in 
Chinese, by the report delivery dates 
 
5.     The consultants will be provided with suitable contacts in the Heilongjiang Financial 
Market Bureau and in MCCs as appropriate. They will be expected to manage and provide all 
international  and  in-country  travel  and  logistics  arrangements,  translation  of  reports,  and 
computers and/or materials for their research and analysis.
